SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A LIST OF SASKATCHEWAN FOR THE PERSON GIVING HIS OR HER QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to answer a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer. If there is not sufficient space to express your answers, use sheets of paper. If there is not sufficient space to express your answers, use sheets of paper. If there is not sufficient space to express your answers, use sheets of paper.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check next to it.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: Wm. Beckley
2. Your address: Lucky Lake, Sask.
3. Date: May 7th
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) Redwood County, Minnesota U.S.A.
5. What was your father's name and occupation? George Beckley, Farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) Aug. 1905
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. Atlin 1898, Dawson 1900, N.W.T.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may say "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc). 29
9. What were your reasons for coming West? Start farming & make a home
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?). All three
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?  
   Though it advisable.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?  
    By myself

13. What means of transportation did you use?  
    Railroad, Horses & democrat and by foot.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.).  
    Crossing the Saskatchewan river on the ice in March 1906. With team of horses & own plow + camping equipment. Breaking through at this side. But no losses.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?  
    In Regina

16. Where did you settle or take up land?  
    Sec 24 Tp 25 Rg 8. West 3rd

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.  
    None

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?  
    Farming & placer & quartz mining  
    Farming
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   Once a month

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date
    and place of marriage. Minnie D. Christoffers
    26th of Jan 1910 at Moose Jaw.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place
    to settle?
    John McConachie

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West
    tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your
    memory which you would like to record?
    Every one was very sociable

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church,
    visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
    Quite a lot. Attending church in summer after 1909
    Visiting friends. 8 miles to social evenings.
    By Horse.
    For Business 65 miles to Davidson
25. When was the first car used in the community? 1913

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Davidson 65 miles.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   No. Elbow, Morris Bridgford, & a little store at the river. Now the Riverhurst Ferry.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   Just when necessary.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   1922.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   In 1909 Clothing the Main Store.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   In 1920. Saskatchewan Telephone Company.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   Yes.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Not many.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

Yes No

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Pres of the Grain Growers 1913
County of this Municipality 1915

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

First Combine 1929
Threshing outfit 1909
Organizing the Greenbriar School

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above. In (2), (3), (4).

The Green Briar School was taken from a school name in Michigan, U.S.A.

Lucky Lake was named after a lake 4 miles north of town.

Fullis was named after a settler John Fullis.
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

Would you or the person who owns them either

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying? .......

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon?.... (indicate your preference, if any) ..................

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

One Daughter was a R.N., nurse now married living in Montreal.
One Daughter was teacher now married living at P.A.
One Daughter was teacher now married living in Cochrane.
Teaching at Greenbriar School the last two years.
We have 5 grandchildren.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

Growing wheat on a big scale with big machinery.

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

Mr. Andrew Morgan Lucky Lake, Sask.
Mr. George Geil Lucky Lake, Sask.
Mr. H.C. Grose Lucky Lake, Sask.
